comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Eyelightfilms this was infrastructural vandalism as well!  Isn't this a nice building?  I like the style of it, really well designed and constructed of good materials that lasted the pace!

comment.author: 56105315@N07
comment._content: At least being in Dublin it'll be a tad more authentic than the "Oirish" pubs on every street in every town in the world! Yes, love the cars too, a Ford Zodiac I think, or maybe a Zephyr?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/56105315@N07] Oh thanks, because I wasn't sure! That shape always screams Ford Anglia at me...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/56105315@N07] The car in front of the station is either a Consul or a Zephyr. The Zodiac had a larger grill. The black car to far left is a Mkll Consul. You can see the name on the boot lid. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Yes indeed. Vandalism on every front. I maintain that much of the FF/Todd Andrews hatred of the railways was due to them being built by people they perceived as "British". Same as their attitude to Georgian Dublin. By the 1930s, plans were discussed in Éamon de Valera's government to demolish all of Merrion Square, perhaps the most intact of the five squares, on the basis that the houses were "old fashioned" and "un-national". They were only saved by Adolf Hitler's invasion of Poland in 1939 and a general lack of capital and investment; the plans were put on hold in 1939 and forgotten about by 1945.... ....The decision in the late 1950s to demolish a row of Georgian houses in Kildare Place and replace them with a brick wall was greeted with jubilation by a republican minister at the time, Kevin Boland, who said they stood for everything he opposed.

comment.author: 65930405@N04
comment._content: We'd be back living in wattle and daub huts if some of the lads back then had their day.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
That car opposite is quite new, maybe only 6 months old.

Dublin registrations AYI 1 to YYI 999 (Nov 1957 - Oct 1959) so SYI 591 is a 1959 reg from maybe March.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Thanks to [http://www.flickr.com/photos/56105315@N07] and [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] for the info on the Fords, and to [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] for reg. no. information.

comment.author: 77191617@N03
comment._content: For six days each week I attended a school just down Harcourt St to the left, and occasionally took the train to visit my aunt in Dundrum, carefully avoiding a smut in the eye when leaning out the carriage window to admire the view from the Nine Arches bridge at Milltown. The station steps would be thronged on Saturday mornings with boys eagerly devouring "gur" cakes, produced by a bakery directly across the street from the station, and utilising all the unsold sweet cake from the previous week.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77191617@N03] That's a bit harsh, isn't it, school Monday to Saturday? And haven't had gur cake in years, yummy! Have you seen this photo of the last train ever from Harcourt Street?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 53686581@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mogey] It looks very nice! Glad to see it's in use and well-kept!

comment.author: 12458821@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] The VW wasn't that old either - the big back window came in for model year 1958 with a build date of September 1957 at the earliest.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/12458821@N08] Thanks, and that "big back window" tip may come in very handy for dating 1950s photos...
